intro: Oxygraphis plantaginifolia, commonly known as the common oxygraphis, is a herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of the northern hemisphere. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and features lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy surface. The plant produces small, clustered flowers in shades of pink to purple, which bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges or stream banks. Its foliage is used in traditional herbal medicine for its purported diuretic and anti-inflammatory properties.
